Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Story: I stood at the edge of the living room, my mother’s voice echoing in my ears as she handed me the ceremonial candle. “It’s your turn to lead this year,” she said, her eyes shining with pride and expectation. My family watched, waiting for me to honor our tradition, to show that I understood the importance of our heritage. But my mind kept drifting back to the pool, where I worked as a lifeguard. I remembered the supervisor’s reminder that morning: “Everything must be perfect—no exceptions. Even the smallest detail matters.” I had noticed the pool chairs were a bit out of line, not enough to be dangerous, but enough to break the standard I was supposed to uphold. My hands trembled as I held the candle, feeling the weight of my family’s hopes and the responsibility of my job pressing in from both sides. I wanted to make my parents proud, to show respect for our traditions, but I also couldn’t shake the nagging thought that I was letting my team down. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, torn between the two worlds that demanded all of me at once.
